Description: A rectangular fragment of carved ivory or bone: probably part of a box, broken off at the upper edge. The front surface bears an incised scene showing a figure of a captive with his arms bound behind his back. In front of the figure is a carved border, of the same style as that found on the strips of ivory inlay of the period. The edges of the piece have been carefully finished and the back is flat, with four incised cuts at the edges. Good condition.
Curator's comments: Bibliography: A. Roveri and F. Tiradritte [eds.], 'Kemet: Alle Sorgenti del Tempo' (Ravenna, 1998), p.208 [166]; W. M. F. Petrie, 'Royal Tombs of the Earliest Dynasties' II, pl. IIIA, I; J. Capart, ‘Les Débuts de L’Art, 245, fig. 174, bottom left; J. Capart, ‘Primitive Art', 253, fig. 190, bottom left; See also P. Kaplony, 'Die Inschriften der Ägyptischen Frühzeit I (Wiesbaden, 1963), 208; P. Kaplony, 'Die Inschriften der Ägyptischen Frühzeit II (Wiesbaden, 1964), 901, n. 1183, where this object is incorrectly equated with Petrie, 'Royal Tombs of the Earliest Dynasties' II, pl. IIIA, 2.
